Dans l'Antiquité, ceux qui régnaient sur le monde portaient un simple bonnet et un col de fourrure roulé. [In ancient times there were those who simple caps... and (yet) ruled the word is the Chinese construction. Not ALL rulers were of this kind. 陳廣忠 gets this right: 有头戴兜婺翻卷领部而统冶天下的.]

Dans l'Antiquité, ceux qui régnaient sur le monde portaient un simple bonnet et un col de fourrure roulé. ["In ancient times there were those who simple caps... and (yet) ruled the world) is the Chinese construction. Not ALL rulers were of this kind. 陳廣忠 gets this right, the Westerners seem to get it wrong: 有头戴兜婺翻卷领部而统冶天下的.]
Leur vertu se manifestait par la vie et non par la mort, [Even 陳廣忠 can only offer a paraphrase, but it is a helpful one: ，他们实行德政使人民繁衍而不加杀害，
par le don et non par la dépossession.

Dans l'Antiquité, ceux qui régnaient sur le monde portaient un simple bonnet et un col de fourrure roulé. ["In ancient times there were those who simple caps... and (yet) ruled the world) is the Chinese construction. Not ALL rulers were of this kind. 陳廣忠 gets this right, the Westerners seem to get it wrong, and the free Russian version gets nowhere: 有头戴兜婺翻卷领部而统冶天下的.]

Le duc Xiao (Les editions courantes écrivent fautivement "duc Zhao de Lu") eut une mère adoptive qui'il aimait. [§§§§慈母"adoptive mother" who is appointed by a ruler, would have to be distinguished from an ordinary (wet)nurse. HYDCD: 2.古稱撫育自己成長的庶母爲慈母。《儀禮·喪服》：“慈母如母。傳曰：慈母者何也?傳曰：妾之無子者，妾子之無母者，父命妾曰：女以爲子；命子曰：女以爲母。若是，則生養之，終其身如母，死則喪之三年如母。”]

Le duc Xiao (Les editions courantes écrivent fautivement "duc Zhao de Lu") eut une mère adoptive qui'il aimait. [§§§§慈母"adoptive mother" who is appointed by a ruler, would have to be distinguished from an ordinary (wet)nurse. HYDCD: 2.古稱撫育自己成長的庶母爲慈母。《儀禮·喪服》：“慈母如母。傳曰：慈母者何也?傳曰：妾之無子者，妾子之無母者，父命妾曰：女以爲子；命子曰：女以爲母。若是，則生養之，終其身如母，死則喪之三年如母。” Presumably Duke Xiao must have been his father's son by a concubine who died very early so that his father appointed an "adoptive mother". 待考]

Où donc trouverait-on des lois constantes dans le monde? [How could there be one unchanging rule to follow in this world?" 高注：言人能考度其才，時省其行，擇其善者而崇用之，不必循常，故曰「雖日變可也」。唯仁義不可改耳，故[曰]萬世不更矣。 Chen Guangzhong is clearly superior to all the Westerners: "至于像用人考核他的才能，而按时察看他们的政绩，即使说每天有新的变化也是可以的，天下难道有什么固定不变的常规吗？同社会时事相合，符合人的常理，顺应天地的变化，对鬼神和顺，那么就能得到整治了。”Excerpt From淮南子--传世经典 文白对照 (中华书局出品)[西汉]刘安撰 陈广忠译

Où donc trouverait-on des lois constantes dans le monde? [How could there be one unchanging rule to follow in this world?" 高注 sees the need for an explanation of the argument here：言人能考度其才，時省其行，擇其善者而崇用之，不必循常，故曰「雖日變可也」。唯仁義不可改耳，故[曰]萬世不更矣。 Chen Guangzhong is clearly superior to all the Westerners: "至于像用人考核他的才能，而按时察看他们的政绩，即使说每天有新的变化也是可以的，天下难道有什么固定不变的常规吗？同社会时事相合，符合人的常理，顺应天地的变化，对鬼神和顺，那么就能得到整治了。”Excerpt From淮南子--传世经典 文白对照 (中华书局出品)[西汉]刘安撰 陈广忠译

塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"?
塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"? I read this very differently than Lynn, the idea is that if one promotes de it hinders the natural functioning of one's xing.

塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"? I read this very differently than Lynn, the idea is that if one promotes de it hinders the natural functioning of one's xing. It appears he is following Wang Niansun's emendation. However, Cheng Xuanying and the earlier commentators read 塞 ("hinder/obstruct") .

塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"? I read this very differently than Lynn, the idea is that if one promotes de it hinders the natural functioning of one's xing. It appears he is following Wang Shumin's emendation (based on Wang Niansun). However, Cheng Xuanying and the earlier commentators read 塞 ("hinder/obstruct"). He is letting the later textual scholarship guide his translation here, despite his claim to read it as Guo Xiang would have.

et aucun royaume de dix mille chars ne pourrat être écrasé et anéanti! ["imperiled" is distinctly wrong] BH: The French transl. does not follow the TLS text. The Engl. does. The original text in Liu Wendian's edition has as the second line "among countries with ten thousand chariots none was not destroyed. “ So there is a need for re-reading, following Wang Niansun etc. "ruo ci" could possibly introduce an irrealis which the English ignore in translating "This being the case". I would read the whole passage from this perspective. Material resources do not guarantee success as shown by the example of Jie and Zhou.
at revera etiam fugerunt.》

BH: The French transl. does not follow the TLS text. [[NB: we follow the DC Lao text, like the English.]] The Engl. does. The original text in Liu Wendian's edition has as the second line "among countries with ten thousand chariots none was not destroyed. “ So there is a need for re-reading, following Wang Niansun etc. "ruo ci" could possibly introduce an irrealis which the English ignore in translating "This being the case". I would read the whole passage from this perspective. Material resources do not guarantee success as shown by the example of Jie and Zhou.

num montium fluviorumque dii ipsi relinquent, id est, num volent non exposcere ut in victimam sibi offeratur? [Tcheou regum tempore, homines faciebant plurimi rubeam victimam, utebantur rufo bove. Variis maculis versicolor bos certe non potest explere victimae usum. Attamen ab illo generatus pullus, si ejus colos sit rubeus et rufus, congruenter potest tenere locum illius (id est, mactari pro illo). Tchoung koung pater erat vilis, et (patris) actiones praecae. Ideo Philosophus cum illis (bovibus) comparat eos; et dicit patris prava non posse delere sui filii bona; si Tchoung koung sit bonus et peritus, eum profecto esse adhibendum in saeculo, (id est, constituendum esse magistratum, ut prosit aequalibus suis).

The matter under discussion here, if properly understood in all the necessary philological detail is of the greatest significance for the history of religion in China." 陶鴻慶云:「見、聞」上皆當有「獨」字，惟其獨見，故不可布於海內，惟其獨聞，故不可明於百姓，即承上「天下之怪物，聖人之所獨聞見」而言。蓋「獨見，獨聞」之理微而難知，非世俗所能犏喻，故必託於機祥而爲之教誡也。下文皆本此義而申説之。今本奪兩「獨」字，則文義

Aussi, ce qu l'homme saint a perçu ne peut être divulgué à l'interieur des mers, [§§§§§§夫"pre-nominal topic marker introducing non-narrative discourse: as for" is not grammatically recognised in the English, and it is not clear where the unbracketed "Because" in the English comes from. §§§§§見"here: what has been seen (only by the sages)" is misconstrued in the English. §§§§§§不可布於海內"must not be divulged to the whole world within the four seas" is not recognised as the predicate at all in the English. Thus at this point the English gets us nowhere. 陳廣忠 is unfortunately not pinning down the subject here but gets the gist of what is going on here: 所看见的东西不可能在天下宣布. 許匡一 sees the problem and goes in for a generic subject "some things": 有些现象不能公布於天下. I suspect that the 見 here are the visions of the sages. The matter under discussion here, if properly understood in all the necessary philological detail is of the greatest significance for the history of religion in China." 陶鴻慶云 seems to have a nominal reading of 見 and 聞:「見、聞」上皆當有「獨」字，惟其獨見，故不可布於海內，惟其獨聞，故不可明於百姓，即承上「天下之怪物，聖人之所獨聞見」而言。蓋「獨見，獨聞」之理微而難知，非世俗所能犏喻，故必託於機祥而爲之教誡也。下文皆本此義而申説之。今本奪兩「獨」字，則文義不明。

C'est pourquoi il a instauré des prohibitions relatives aux mânes et aux esprits, aux présages fastes et funestes. [§§鬼神禨祥"auspicious and inauspicious omens from the ghosts and spirits" is grammatically misconstrued, I think, and pointlessly relegated to "[vulgar beliefs]". 陳廣忠 spells out a plausible reading involving the "auspicious and inauspicious signs of the ghosts and spirits": 因此便按照鬼神所显示的凶吉而为百姓立下禁戒， 許匡一 also distances himself from superstition in his translation: 因此就利用鬼神决定吉凶祸福的迷信观念来定出种种禁忌，

Il classifie les formes, en déduit les catégories auxquelles elles appartiennent et considère que les métapmorphoses ne sont, en fait, que des changements d'images. [陳廣忠 flaunders just as much as the English. The French misconstrues 變象"HYDCD: 變異的自然現象changing natural phenomena/appearances". I suggest: "But they deem them to be mere appearances subject to change". The English makes no sense to me.][BH This translation, perfect as it is, does not seem to fit the context. The point is not what the sage makes of them but how he puts them to use to impress others. The English archaeological interpretation is far-fetched. The changing appearances are those mentioned in the following.]

They draw on "expanded forms" (there are real four-footed animals, so why not bixie?) and "extended categories" (thereare ravenous beasts, so why not taotie?)." The repeated "then asked" is bad story telling. It makes everything conjunctive, whereas "replied" would give the sense of one thing following from another.

7.32 Magister ait:
"K'iou precatur jamdiu."

"K'iou precatur jamdiu." [Lei qua quis dolens de alicujus morte, enarrat ejus facta, oratio. Chang hia signifant coelum et terram. Coelestes spiritus dicuntur chenn; terrestres dicuntur k'i. Tao, paenitere culparum, sectari virtutem, hac ope rogare spirituum auxilium. Philosophus dixit: "K'iou precatur jamdudum. Etenim precari nihil aliud est quam sectari virtutem, corrigere vitia sua, et ita quaerere sprituum opem. Ego omnibus diebus, si habeam quid vitiosum, certe corrigo; si qua sit virtus, certe prosequor. Vere mea precatio ad spirituales intelligentias facta continua est. Quomodo exspectassem usque ad hodiernum diem, (antequam precarer)?"

et populus non assecutus est ut laudibus celebraret eum." [Olim Tcheou regni T'ai wang antiquus princeps genuit tres filios, quorum natu maximus fuit T'ai pe. alter Thoung ioung, tertius Ki li. Ki li genuit filium Tch'ang, qui factus est Wenn wang. T'ai wang, noscens Wenn wang praeditum esse summis virtutibus, voluit tradere principis dignitatem (tertio filio suo) Ki li, ut adveniret ad Wenn wang. T'ai pe cognoscens hoc, statim cum fratre minore Tchoung ioung praetendit causam quod vellet colligere medicinales herbas, et fugiens adiit australium barbarorum regiones (provinciam Hou kouang locumve remotiorem). T'ai wang tunc tradidit dignitatem Ki li. Quando advenit Ou want (cujus pater fuit Wenn wang), Ou wang habuit universum imperium Ex illo tempore si consideretur illud (quod factum est a T'ai pe), tantummodo cessit regnum, (scilicet, Tcheou regnum); sed si ex praesenti tempore perpendamus illud, revera totus imperii vastitatem profecto cessit fratris filio et non accepit. Sed ille cessit, latuit, evanuit, nec fuerunt vestigia quae possent videri. Ideo populus non assecutus est ut laudibus celebraret eum. T'ai pe fecit ut sua persona et nomen simul laterent, et mundus et ipsemet invicem obliviscerentur. Illa est quae dicenda est summa virtus.

Et nunc et in posterum, ego scio me potuisse vitare (omnem corporis laesionem), o parvi filii." [Pater et mater quod integrum genuerunt, si filius integrum reddat (terrae); si, nulla amissa sui corporis parte, non dedecore afficiat suos parentes; tum primum dicendus est pius in parentes. Etenim, gerere seipsum juxta virtutis viam, illustrare parentes, clarum facere nomen (suum et parentum), profecto est filialis pietatis praecipua pars; at qui integrum servat suum corpus, certe valet integras (honestas) servare suas actiones. Corpus et membra ipsa non licet non integra servare; quanto minus licet non integras servare suas actiones, et ita dedecorare suos parentes?]

Car, où qu'il soit, la multitude des êtres élèvent le regard vers lui. [§§§§§§The last two lines are not properly linked together syntactically, as they must be, and i am glad to find that this is how also 許匡一 takes this passage: 天道的尊贵，不只是像天子的尊严那样，仅仅当他出现在那里的时候众人才做出敬仰的样子来。 陳廣忠 is less explicit, but basically has the same understanding of the link: 天道的尊贵．更不只是像天子那样的尊崇，所在的地方众人仰慕他。 牟愛鵬 964 concurs. I am interested to note the general agreement on this point because, of course, although nobody seems to have noticed this, this passage is daologically absolutely crucial, lifting - as it does! - the religious daological realm of veneration above the political. Taoist veneration is ideologically and explicitly elevated as something "not merely like" the veneration of an emperor.

n'a rien à voir avec l'hommage qu'on rend au fils du Ciel. Car, où qu'il soit, la multitude des êtres élèvent le regard vers lui. [§§§§§§The last two lines are not properly linked together syntactically, as they must be, and i am glad to find that this is how also 許匡一 takes this passage: 天道的尊贵，不只是像天子的尊严那样，仅仅当他出现在那里的时候众人才做出敬仰的样子来。 陳廣忠 is less explicit, but basically has the same understanding of the link: 天道的尊贵．更不只是像天子那样的尊崇，所在的地方众人仰慕他。 劉康德：這道的尊嚴不只像天子的尊嚴，那樣只當天子出現的時候民眾才敬仰他。 牟愛鵬 964 concurs. Pomeranceva: а в том, что там, где оно присутствует, все обращено к нему. I am interested to note the general agreement on this point of syntax first because, of course, although nobody seems to have noticed this, this passage is daologically absolutely crucial, lifting - as it does! - the religious daological realm of veneration above the political. Taoist veneration is ideologically and explicitly elevated as something "not merely like" the veneration of an emperor.
